name: UNC2970 Operation MISTPEN
description: TTPs identified from Operation MISTPEN of UNC2970

techniques.comment: Mandiant noticed an intrusion leveraging a job-themed phishing email from WhatsApp to social engineer a victim to download a malicious archive.
The attackers masqueraded as a recruiter for prominent companies, copying and tailoring job descriptions.
The backdoor communicates using HTTP with compromised WordPress websites belonging to small businesses from across the world.
UNC2970 used a job description in PDF file format shared with the victim to execute the MISTPEN backdoor through a trojanized version of SumatraPDF.
The trojanized dynamic-link library (DLL) file libmupdf.dll creates a scheduled task to execute the backdoor daily using the Windows binary BdeUISrv.exe.
The attackers used encryption (in this case, ChaCha20) to protect the command and control channel.
The backdoor DLL is decrypted and then reflectively loaded into the memory space of SumatraPDF.exe and executed.
UNC2970 relied on legitimate job description content to target victims employed in U.S. critical infrastructure.
UNC2970 uses a scheduled task named "Sumatra Launcher" for persistence which executes the backdoor daily when the user logs in.
An encrypted ZIP archive was used to deliver the job description to the victim and to extract specific required information.
MISTPEN decrypts a token using AES to access the Microsoft API endpoint.
UNC2970 modifies the open-source code of an older SumatraPDF version, using it to avoid detection by security measures.
UNC2970 uses a trojanized version of a legitimate Notepad++ plugin to download and execute Portable Executable (PE) files.
The backdoor DLL MISTPEN is decrypted and loaded into the memory space of SumatraPDF.exe and executed.
